Hopkins climbed the first rung
of the ladder for the State championship when she triumphed in a
hard-fought contest over the srcappy and fast Western Maryland
team on Saturday by the score of
9 to 0. The lion's share of the
credit for the victory goes to 011ie
Whislow, who took the starch out
of the Upstaters with a beautiful
40-yard goal from placement in
the first few minutes of play, who
skirted the ends time and again
for Hopkins' most substantial
gains, and who piloted the team
through a trying contest with
masterly skill and judgment. The
Hopkins team packed a real, driving punch and, for ilie first time
this year, came through with flying colors. It was a great victory
and the stage was all set for it.
The Hopkins battalion, in olive
drab, in full force, aird preceded
by a fancy brass band, paraded to
Homewood field where they manoeuvered as a preliminary attraction to the big show. The student
body of Western Maryland was
not to be outdone and was there
with its band. The largest crowd
of the year, numbering about four
thousand, filled the stands and
lined the field.
The Hopkins Machine worked
smoothly and steadily under the
guiding hand of their clever quarter, and at times exhibited flashes
that recalled the old steam-roller
days of 1915. Winslow drove the
team at top speed and had them
fighting harder than ever before
and personally contributed liberally to the success of the team.
Woodward, Carey and Jones also
came in for their share of the
honors. The Hopkins captain outpunted his rival by many yards,
booting the ball for flights that
averaged 50 yards. Carey, who
made Hopkins' only score last
week, is rapidly developing into a
star half-back ; with a burst of
speed and force, he consistently
bored his way through the Green
and Gold line, and finally carried
the ball over the line for the lone
touchdown. Jones, on account of
a bad leg, was not given too much
work, but whenever he was given
the ball, the "Speed-the-plough"
demon delivered the goods. The
line, although it had the advantage in weight, did not play up to
usual form, and for that reason
the Western Maryland team was
always ,dangerous.

That a" constitution correlating
all the activities of the University
be immediately drawn up was the
decision of the Student Council at
its regular monthly meeting last
Monday night. A committee was
appointed to communicate with
the governing student organizations of other Universities in regard to their methods of relating
the branches of student interests,
as well as to make a thorough
study of our own activities and
lie proper manner of co-ordinating
them.
The student council then turned
its attention to the all-important
question of hazing. After much
discussion it was decided to delegate to the "Pep committee" of the
Sophomore Class the power both
to conduct a roll-call of the freshmen at each football game, and to
pass upon the excuses for absence.
All excuses which this committee
considers unsatisfactory are then
reported to the Student Council
for recommendation as to the best
method for dealing with the offender. Completing this important phase of the question, the
Council took up the subject of
hazing in general. This body felt
upon the conclusion of the discussion that the attitude of the
lower classes did not appear to be
exactly the proper one,as all forms
of pure hazing have long since
been abolished at Hopkins, and
there remains only the rudimentary forms serving as penalties for
disobedience to the regulations.
In order to correct this improper
conception, it was decided to send
representatives to the next meeting of the lower classes.
A particularly flagrant case of
utter disregard of all regulations
having been summoned before the
Council was then giving a hearing. Yaffe, '21, speaking in his
own defense, noted as extenuating
circumstance the fact that he had
attended another institution for
two weeks and while there he had
complied with the regulations. It
was admitted, however, upon crossexamination that he knew of the
requirement in the University requiring all students to obey the
freshmen regulations until they
shall have completed one semester
in either this cir another University. The Council finally decided
the defendant guilty of breaking
the regulations, and as a penalty
will compel him to obey them during both semesters.

Approximately s800 has been
raised as a result of a campaign
for the Students' Friendship War
Fund held on Thursday and Friday of last week at the University under the auspices of the Y.
M. C. A. A million dollars is being raised for this fund throughout all the colleges of the country,
and up to the time of this article
going to press, the above amount
has been subscribed at Hopkins,
with 300 of the student body yet
unheard from. A central committee was gotten together earlier in
the week, and the need was presented to them, with the result
that the twenty-seven men in that
small group pledged themselves
for over $540.
This central
group was organized into committees, a certain number of men
to each class, and the campaign
proper was started at a massmeeting on Thursday noon, with a
talk by Mr. David Porter, secretary of the central board of the
V. M. C. A.
Mr. Porter said in opening that
he thought this was the most momentous proposal ever brought before the University. "We hear so
much of the five millions of men
who are lying wounded in the hospitals of Europe, and we know
what those men have sacrificed
and are sacrificing for the common
cause of us all. We too must
learn what sacrificing means,
when these men,some of them now
our friends, cousins and brothers,
are sacrificing so much."
There are more than six million
men in the prison camps of Europe today, and Mr. Porter then
told of the conditions under which
most of those men are living; their
quarters being low huts without
any artificial heat, enclosed on all
sides by barbed wire and machine
guns, with the men's cots built up
in tiers three deep. Many of these
men are college students and high
school graduates accustomed to
luxury.
The speaker stated that one of
the worst features of the life in
these prison camps is its awful
tedium, which has rendered thousands of inmates insane and has
brought thousands more to a state
closely bordering on insanity. Mr.
Porter recounted several incidents
in lint. He stated that it was
just this state of affairs which the
Students' Friendship War Fund
has.been 'organized to combat. Its
promoters hope to introduce into
the prison camps features of an
educational and fraternal nature,

The team from Western Maryland College came to Homewood
Saturday well trained, fast and
over-brimming with confidence because of an hitherto clean slate,
as they had defeated all their previous opponents, including St.
John's College. Our team rose to
the occasion, however, and by
skillful playing in the first half
secured a lead sufficient to permit them to come out victorious.
Much had been said of the tricky
nature of the Western Maryland
attack, but it was very manifest
that it was not by tricks that they
made their notable advances, but
rather by a well-planned and wellexecuted series of line plunges. In
football, as in life, tricks do not
avail one much if the good, hard
work on fundamentals and the exercise of the intelligence are neglected.
The team is entitled to a great
deal of credit for the manner in
which they played Saturday, because for many of them it was the
first championship game in which
they had participated and each
man felt just how much was at
- stake. There is not a man on the
team that did not give all that
was in him, and it must have
pleased Hopkins men to see their,
for the most part, untried fellows
stop such a sterling little player
as is Keller, for his skill in all of
his previous games has been most
striking. So well did each man do •
his allotted portion that it would
seem unjust to single out individuals for commendation, yet one
cannot help but praise Captain
Woodward for the way in which
he set the pace for his men and
Winslow for his subperb generalship.
The winning of this game by no
means spells perfection for the
team, and I am sure that no one
is. more aware of this than each
member of the squad. It is doubtful, and this is said without the
least intention of detracting from
the credit earned by the team Saturday, if the same sort of game
would be enough to defeat St.
John's, as St. John's stands today.
It is of course a fact that Western Maryland defeated St. John's,
but all of us know only too well
that facts and logic often go
awry when applied to a St. John'sHopkins game. From now until
November 24 every effort will be
made to so perfect our play that
on the evening of that day we
may be one game nearer the
championship than we now are.

Major Guild Urges Better Attendance and
Strict Military Discipline—Battalion
Leaders Speak—First Dance
on November 16

At an assembly last Thursday
Major Guild presented for the first
time to the men his chief policy
for bringing the corps to a state
of utmost efficiency and making
the Hopkins battalion the best of
its kind. "I believe," he said,"that
a set of principles which in the future will become customs, formulated and lived up to by the men
themselves without orders from
any authority is the best way to
reach this goal." He deplored the
fact that the present laxity in
spirit was such that if the rate of
delinquencies was not made substantially lower he would be obliged to report certain habitual
absentees to the dean for expulsion.
After Major Guild had opened
the meeting, Mr. Kistler spoke enthusiastically of the spirit of the
company teams. He also very earnestly asked that the men give
their full support to the battalion
dance.
The meeting was then turned
over to the battalion, and Captain
Bitter urged that every man see
to it that he carries himself with
a soldierly bearing, whether in
uniform or not. Captain Baxley
next brought up the subject of the
battalion dance. The committee
having it in charge, which is composed of the captains, first lieutenants and the adjutant, has set
the date of the first dance for Friday, November 16, at 8.30 P. M.
To pay for the music, janitor's
service and light refreshments,
each man will be taxed forty
cents. Mr. Kistler will be on hand
at 8 o'clock to give instruction to
those who need and desire it.
Captain Chisholm then talked
on the wearing of the uniform and
of the conduct of the men while
in uniform. He made it plain
that the Hopkins uniform should
be distinctive and respected in
every way. Especially, he said,
uniforms should always be kept
neat and clean.
Following the talks of the officers, first sergeants Simon and
Smith each treated the subject of
saluting, the former urging that
the battalion adopt the custom of
saluting the battalion officers and
the latter presenting the question
of saluting professors.
After these talks a committee
of three men from each company
was elected to draw up a set of
policies and present them to the
battalion for adoption. The committee consists of the company
commanders ex officio and the following men: Company A,Almy and
Cattanach ; Company B, Wagner
and Kirk; Company C, Gardner
and Rothschild. ,

I think that there is no general

Major Guild and Dr. Kouwenhoven to
Give Instruction to Engineering
Seniors in Battalion for Commissions in Signal Corps.

Dr. Kouwenhoven, head of the
department of electrical engineering, in co-operation with Major
Guild, is preparing to offer a
course in signal engineering which
will be open to seniors in engineering who are members of the
University battalion. It will include theoretical and practical
work in telegraph, telephone and
radio signalling. The purpose of
the course is to train men to take
positions as officers in the Army
Signal Corps.
Major Guild is himself an expert
telegrapher. He has written a
number of valuable papers on this
subject and has taken out several
patents in telegraphy.

The Student Council.

The Student Council has at last
shaken off its lethargy and is literally jumping into its proper
place as the dominant and controlling body in college life. After its whirlwind round up of disobedient freshmen and others disregardful of Hopkins traditions
last week, no student will doubt
that he is beyond the reach of its
long arm, but will realize that upholding the University traditions
and regulations is not only his
duty but the best policy for him
to pursue. There shall be no
quibbling hereafter on the part of
freshmen as to whether they wear
caps and buttons or not; that is
definitely understood.
But let no one think that the
Student Council is merely a police
court for offenders of the law. It
is infinitely more than that. It
is composed of men who are elected by the students and who are
working for the best interests of
the students. It is the recognized
medium between the undergraduates and the faculty. The biggest
and most important of its present
chosen tasks is to frame a constitution which will establish on a
firm basis for all time the status
of each student activity, and crystallize in the finest form many of
the yet unwritten traditions. The
time is at an end for one to smile
when the name of the Student
Council is mentioned. That body
is going to make itself felt in
every line of student endeavor. It
will be a high court of justice, a
respected legislature and administrative body, and the champion of
Hopkins traditions. It is the duty
of each one of us to become its
ardent supporter.

The Time Is Not Ripe.

The decision of the Athletic
Board not to recognize basket-ball
and swimming is undoubtedly a
hard blow to the two small groups
of enthusiasts who so earnestly
presented petitions for the official
acknowledgement of these minor
sports as forms of Hopkins athletics.
This decision was not a hasty
one by any means, but was made
after a long discussion as to
whether basket-ball and swimming
teams could this year take the
place which should be accorded
them in college activities. There
are many valid objections, and
even those who may be most disappointed by the outcome of the
board meeting, can see the justice
of the decision.
The obstacles may be summed
up in two sentences. In the first

A close view of the life at Camp
Meade is given in the following letter from "Jack" Mowbray,'17, sergeant in the 315th Infantry. Besides telling interesting incidents,
he speaks of several Hopkins men.
"Hank" Chalmers, one of them,
was a member of the present Senior Class, manager of baseball, a
lacrosse star and assistant general
secretary of the Hopkins Y. M. C.

Lindley, formerly in charge of the
Y. M. C. A. work at Hopkins, and

CAMP MEADE,
October 30, 1917.
DEAR CARROLL:
One thing I forgot to speak of
in my last letter is the three Hopkins men who are doing their bit
here. Do you remember Sergeant
Freelander? Well, he is captain
of Company I in our regiment,
the 315th. He has been very nice
to us since our arrival and we recall happy days at Hopkins when
peace reigned supreme in our fair
land. (That was a nice, worn-out
phrase.) The other two are
"Hank" Chalmers,'18, and Mr. A.
E. Lindley, last year's collegiate
secretary. They are both together
here in charge of our branch Y.
M.C.A. "Hank" is doing very well
here and is very popular. He is
showing fine spirit when he knows
he will be rejected on account of
his eyes in the draft. He anxiously awaits orders to go across the
pond and is working hard to go
over as soon as he can. It is very
amusing to see him "impersonate"
an officer (if that is a good military term). He wears the Y. M.
C. A. uniform, which is a gray
color, but he covers it with a short
sheepskin-lined coat such as all
officers here wear. Almost every
rookie salutes and "Hank" is as
gracious as a major-general in his
return.
Warner and I are now on special
duty. We are sergeants in charge
of the work done by the prisoners
in camp and their number is
legion. You should see us directing the handling of large boxes of
rubbish, trash, etc., seated on the
wagon seat of a big army wagon.
Our pride at being sergeants far
exceeds any feelings of anticipation we might have had at Fort
Myer. A sergeant seems to be a
great man among real men. A
lieutenant—well, why pick on such
a small potato? One of the characters here is Sergeant Wheating.
He is filling out his eleventh enlistment, i. e., his thirty-third
year. He possesses fifty-two good
teeth and a clean record. He expects to be retired this year and
pensioned on account of his long
service.
Another character is "Bill"
Lupton, otherwise known as
"Hap." Before he was drafted he

had served in the navy as chief
bugler. Of course, he is chief
bugler here. He is full of fun, always happy and quick to speak his
own mind. He must be up and
get his buglers up for first call at
6.20 A. M. One morning he overslept, and the officer of the day
rushed into the room at 6.10 to
wake him up. "Hap" thought it
was one of the privates on guard
and, still half asleep, ejaculated:
"Why in the — don't you wake
a man up at 5.30." The officer
laughed, and as "Hap" stirred
himself, exclaimed: "My, but you
are a sociable fellow to wake up."
The joke was on "Hap."
This will do for today. Have
been detailed to the regimental
coal pile in charge of men shoveling coal for the winter supply. A
good many of the men are foreigners and I have trouble to get them
to understand. They keep telling
me they came to fight, not to shovel
coal. Some dirty job!
Yours,
JACK.

Sir—According to Jewish interpretation of the Scriptures, among
the seven commandments given to
Noah and his sons (incumbent
therefore on all mankind to observe) was "not to eat a member

that among some barbarous tribes

ask a savant for solution of the
problem. What answer will the
historical societies then give?
Will they actually believe that the
jitney driver actually transgressed
the ordinance given to the children of Noah—and made soup of
it? And then the singular form
will require explanation. Yours
in affection for J. H. U..,

American Ambassador to that

about two inches in diameter.

given annually since 1898 by the
Baron Pierre de Coubertin, of
Paris, and is awarded by the University to that student who shall
have delivered the best speech in
a contest in public speaking held
annually in the second half-year.

topic announced some weeks previously, chosen from the field of
French history, politics or literature in the nineteenth centruy.

of the illustrious Frenchman,
Alexis de Tocqueville (1805-1859),
author of the well-known historical and political studies "Ancien
Regime" and "Democratic en
Amerique."

The Student Council.

The Student Council has at last
shaken off its lethargy and is literally jumping into its proper
place as the dominant and controlling body in college life. After its whirlwind round up of disobedient freshmen and others disregardful of Hopkins traditions
last week, no student will doubt
that he is beyond the reach of its
long arm, but will realize that upholding the University traditions
and regulations is not only his
duty but the best policy for him
to pursue. There shall be no
quibbling hereafter on the part of
freshmen as to whether they wear
caps and buttons or not; that is
definitely understood.
But let no one think that the
Student Council is merely a police
court for offenders of the law. It
is infinitely more than that. It
is composed of men who are elected by the students and who are
working for the best interests of
the students. It is the recognized
medium between the undergraduates and the faculty. The biggest
and most important of its present
chosen tasks is to frame a constitution which will establish on a
firm basis for all time the status
of each student activity, and crystallize in the finest form many of
the yet unwritten traditions. The
time is at an end for one to smile
when the name of the Student
Council is mentioned. That body
is going to make itself felt in
every line of student endeavor. It
will be a high court of justice, a
respected legislature and administrative body, and the champion of
Hopkins traditions. It is the duty
of each one of us to become its
ardent supporter.

The Time Is Not Ripe.

The decision of the Athletic
Board not to recognize basket-ball
and swimming is undoubtedly a
hard blow to the two small groups
of enthusiasts who so earnestly
presented petitions for the official
acknowledgement of these minor
sports as forms of Hopkins athletics.
This decision was not a hasty
one by any means, but was made
after a long discussion as to
whether basket-ball and swimming
teams could this year take the
place which should be accorded
them in college activities. There
are many valid objections, and
even those who may be most disappointed by the outcome of the
board meeting, can see the justice
of the decision.
The obstacles may be summed
up in two sentences. In the first
place the introduction of these
teams would be confronted by the
unsettled and abnormal conditions
which are manifestly handicapping the other forms of Hopkins
athletics. Furthermore, the utter
lack of facilities for staging contests would make it impossible to
carry on these activities in a manner befitting major sports.
The board, however, does not
want these sports to die out as
there is still a chance for recognition in the future. The enthusiasts can work toward their desired goal by helping to build up
inter - company and inter - class
basket-ball and swimming, thus
gradually developing a gold mine
of material for the teams when the
proper time comes for recognition.

A close view of the life at Camp
Meade is given in the following letter from "Jack" Mowbray,'17, sergeant in the 315th Infantry. Besides telling interesting incidents,
he speaks of several Hopkins men.
"Hank" Chalmers, one of them,
was a member of the present Senior Class, manager of baseball, a
lacrosse star and assistant general
secretary of the Hopkins Y. M. C.
A. He is now assistant to Mr.
Lindley, formerly in charge of the
Y. M. C. A. work at Hopkins, and
is hoping to be sent across the
Atlantic soon for service in
France:
CAMP MEADE,
October 30, 1917.
DEAR CARROLL:
One thing I forgot to speak of
in my last letter is the three Hopkins men who are doing their bit
here. Do you remember Sergeant
Freelander? Well, he is captain
of Company I in our regiment,
the 315th. He has been very nice
to us since our arrival and we recall happy days at Hopkins when
peace reigned supreme in our fair
land. (That was a nice, worn-out
phrase.) The other two are
"Hank" Chalmers,'18, and Mr. A.
E. Lindley, last year's collegiate
secretary. They are both together
here in charge of our branch Y.
M.C.A. "Hank" is doing very well
here and is very popular. He is
showing fine spirit when he knows
he will be rejected on account of
his eyes in the draft. He anxiously awaits orders to go across the
pond and is working hard to go
over as soon as he can. It is very
amusing to see him "impersonate"
an officer (if that is a good military term). He wears the Y. M.
C. A. uniform, which is a gray
color, but he covers it with a short
sheepskin-lined coat such as all
officers here wear. Almost every
rookie salutes and "Hank" is as
gracious as a major-general in his
return.
Warner and I are now on special
duty. We are sergeants in charge
of the work done by the prisoners
in camp and their number is
legion. You should see us directing the handling of large boxes of
rubbish, trash, etc., seated on the
wagon seat of a big army wagon.
Our pride at being sergeants far
exceeds any feelings of anticipation we might have had at Fort
Myer. A sergeant seems to be a
great man among real men. A
lieutenant—well, why pick on such
a small potato? One of the characters here is Sergeant Wheating.
He is filling out his eleventh enlistment, i. e., his thirty-third
year. He possesses fifty-two good
teeth and a clean record. He expects to be retired this year and
pensioned on account of his long
service.
Another character is "Bill"
Lupton, otherwise known as
"Hap." Before he was drafted he

had served in the navy as chief
bugler. Of course, he is chief
bugler here. He is full of fun, always happy and quick to speak his
own mind. He must be up and
get his buglers up for first call at
6.20 A. M. One morning he overslept, and the officer of the day
rushed into the room at 6.10 to
wake him up. "Hap" thought it
was one of the privates on guard
and, still half asleep, ejaculated:
"Why in the — don't you wake
a man up at 5.30." The officer
laughed, and as "Hap" stirred
himself, exclaimed: "My, but you
are a sociable fellow to wake up."
The joke was on "Hap."
This will do for today. Have
been detailed to the regimental
coal pile in charge of men shoveling coal for the winter supply. A
good many of the men are foreigners and I have trouble to get them
to understand. They keep telling
me they came to fight, not to shovel
coal. Some dirty job!
Yours,
JACK.

Hopkins ambulance unit at Allentown, who was elected manager

Roszel P. Thomsen, his successor

UNITED STATES ARMY AMBULANCE
CORPS,JOHNS HOPKINS UNIT.
November 5, 1917.
DEAR TOMMY:
You,probably wonder why I have
not written before, but I have been
hiking ever since I received your
letter and I am still in the field,
and there is no telling how long I
shall be there.
We took one hike to Wind Gap
and there we met such a storm
it took us almost thirty-six hours
to dry out and thaw out. While
doing so we slept one night in a
dance hall and another night in
some stables, but the mice and rats
worried us some, so we moved on
next clay. We hit Allentown Saturday and were washed out again
on Monday night, but on Wednesday morning we packed up and
moved on once more in an hour's
notice, so you see we live and work
fast.
We are now camped at Guth
Station—about six miles from Allentown. I get in every few days
so it is not so bad. We are sleeping and living in tents, but the
fellows started to dig in and make
dug-outs today,so we shall be more
snug in the future.
Remember me to all the fellows.
Your old friend,
STANLEY.

Mystery! What Happened to the Bone?
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—According to Jewish interpretation of the Scriptures, among
the seven commandments given to
Noah and his sons (incumbent
therefore on all mankind to observe) was "not to eat a member
of living animal." I have heard
that among some barbarous tribes
existed (does it still exist?) the
custom of cutting off a slice of
flesh from a living animal and then
allowing nature to do the healing
act.
Well, I was amused as my eye
caught this passage in John McMowbray's letter to "Dear Carroll," published ill THE NEWS-LETTER of October 29: "An obliging
jitney bus driver immediately accosted us and extracted one bone
from us for the trip to the camp."
In a hundred years (or a thousand years?) a reader going
through a copy cherished by the
descendants of "Dear Carroll" will
doubtless be perplexed and will
ask a savant for solution of the
problem. What answer will the
historical societies then give?
Will they actually believe that the
jitney driver actually transgressed
the ordinance given to the children of Noah—and made soup of
it? And then the singular form
will require explanation. Yours
in affection for J. H. U..,

HELPS BUILD STEEL TRANSPORTS
Prof.Thomas Made Mechanical Engineer
for Huge Ship Building Corporation,
Philadelphia—Work will Probably
Confirm,to End of War.

Prof. Carl C. Thomas, formerly
Professor of mechanical engineering and head of the U. S. Shipping
Board Schools for Navigators and
Marine Engineers at the University, has accepted a position as
mechanical engineer for the American International Shipbuilding
Corporation, 140 North Broad
Street, Philadelphia, Pa.
He left two weeks ago to take
up his duties as manager of a
branch of engineering work in
constructing 120 steel vessels to be
used by the U. S. Government for
transporting troops and supplies
to France. He has charge of the
mechanical equipment of the ships,
hiring men, making contracts, inspecting, and the like.
The American International
Shipbuilding Corporation is a recently organized concern. It is
controlled by the American International Corporation, and is connected With Stone & Webster,
general engineers, of Boston, and
the National City Bank of New
York. The corporation has a shipbuilding yard at Philadelphia, and
has under construction an office
building at 140 North Broad
Street.
Material for the ships is being
ordered by contract now. The
contract of the corporation with
the government calls for the completion of the first lot of ships by
April, 1918. The immediate purpose of these vessels is to serve as
transports and supply ships to our
soldiers and allies. The corporation has at its disposal all the
money and equipment that it can
use in this project.
Being a Marine Engineer, Professor Thomas felt that the call
was especially urgent in view of
the scarcity at the present time
of men trained in that line. The
call of the corporation for him
was put to the University in such
a way that they considered it a
duty to let him go. He has been
given leave of absence for the ensuing academic year. Prof. Smallwood has charge of his class in
mechanical engineering.
Prof. Thomas resigned his position as section chief of the Shipping Board Schools in the Middle
Atlantic District. His successor
in this office has not yet been appointed, but Mr. J. W. Lindau
will direct the Marine Engineering and Navigation. Schools here.
Prof. Thomas will probably be absent until the end of the war.

President Poincare of France
presented early last month with
appropriate ceremony t o th e
American Ambassador to that
country the Tocqueville medal,
which is awarded to the winner
of an annual contest in public
speaking at Johns Hopkins. The
State Department has forwarded
the medal to the University, which
has acknowledged the receipt of
it. In view of the fact that the
medal has been formally presented
to our Government by the President of France and that our political as well as our literary relations with France have recently
become so much more intimate,
the medal takes on added value
and interest.
The letter from the State Department, which accompanied the
medal, read in part:
"This medal was delivered to
the American Ambassador at
Paris by the President of France,
at the Palais de e'Elysee, on October 6, 1917, in the presence of a
distinguished gathering."
The medal is of solid gold and
about two inches in diameter.
On one side is engraved a woman's head with a liberty cap representing "Liberty." It is an exquisite trophy—the most beautiful of its kind given at the University.
The Tocqueville medal has been
given annually since 1898 by the
Baron Pierre de Coubertin, of
Paris, and is awarded by the University to that student who shall
have delivered the best speech in
a contest in public speaking held
annually in the second half-year.
In this contest each speaker discusses some phase of a general
topic announced some weeks previously, chosen from the field of
French history, politics or literature in the nineteenth centruy.
The speeches are delivered in English. The medal is given in honor
of the illustrious Frenchman,
Alexis de Tocqueville (1805-1859),
author of the well-known historical and political studies "Ancien
Regime" and "Democratic en
Amerique."
